nodes.text: Using Support Vector Machines (SVM) for segment classification will improve handwritten numeral recognition rates compared to neural network and Hidden Markov Model based methods
We implemented SVM classifiers (one-versus-rest multi class) trained on extracted features from isolated character samples

Feature extraction used moment invariants (7 original + 7 thinned) and affine moment invariants, producing 18 global features and, for online signals, 350 feature values per example after spatial resampling
SVM models were trained using RBF kernel with grid search to select hyperparameters, final chosen values included C = 8 and a selected gamma

Datasets used include the UCI Optdigits dataset (8x8 preprocessed representation) and a collected Assamese handwritten dataset of 8235 samples from 45 writers; experiments also reference IRONOFF and UNIPEN
Preprocessing included filtration, normalization, thinning and spatial resampling of online signals prior to feature extraction and training/testing split with disjoint training and testing sets
SVM binary classifiers were extended to multi class numeral recognition using one-versus-rest scheme and linear kernel was discussed for training but RBF used in experiments
In an application test using Optdigits entries, the discriminant analysis and classifier correctly identified 98% of the testing data
Comparative experiments show SVM recognition rates are higher than HMM recognition rates across three isolated character databases
Because SVM stores support vectors, its model requires significantly more parameter storage (number of support vectors times number of features ~ 350) than HMM which uses weight sharing
Space-saving for SVM can be achieved by storing compact original online signals with pen-up/pen-down status and expanding model dynamically during recognition
Preliminary isolated character results indicate that replacing NN with SVM at segment classification could improve hybrid SVM/HMM word recognizer performance
Work is ongoing to integrate SVM character recognition into the HMM based word recognition framework, where SVM produces character hypotheses and HMM computes word likelihoods
It is anticipated that due to SVM's better discrimination capability, the hybrid SVM/HMM word recognition rate will exceed that of existing HMM hybrid systems
Limitation: SVMs require careful hyperparameter selection (C and gamma) and potentially large storage for support vectors, which can be mitigated but remains a constraint compared to HMMs
